review_title: Great Tuition Benefit but Low Pay and no Insurance option
pros: This paid just under $7,000 a semester. You had to work 20 hours a week with two different professors in the business school, but as a grad fellow, you got full funding for your MBA (saving $50k). The program is 45 credits and I was able to complete it in two years, including one Summer semester.
cons:
It's an expensive area and $14k isn't enough to live on your own income.

The graduate program had a strict "no other employment" policy, where you couldn't work another part time job during the Fall or Spring semesters. So, you couldn't even supplement the stipend to make it more feasible (if you had to support yourself - luckily I lived with my parents). 

The university didn't provide insurance or have a discounted policy for grad students (if they did, it still wasn't affordable). The University insurance was $4,000 a year but they paid me $6,500 a semester at the time. And I couldn't supplement with another job.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Villanova, PA
pros: Open to new ideas, innovative, friendly
cons: New and growing and would take more time to flourish

pros: Pros good experience good atmosphere
cons: Cons: small pay far from the city

pros: University benefits are comparably good.
cons:
Advancement perpetuates an insular, toxic culture. Across offices and at varying levels, egos and agendas are at play more often working toward common outcomes. Petty political power struggles make the work unduly entrenched and difficult to move forward.

There is an invisible playbook of abuse and manipulation. Some experience a deceptive bait and switch in terms of their jobs, they are set up to fail, or they are put in a position to be abused and manipulated and then victim-blamed in turn. Those without power, who don't fit the mold, who speak up in self-advocacy or resist the culture are vulnerable to victimization. 

Tactics run the gamut: high-school games of in group/out group, unprofessional and inappropriate gossip, shunning and ostracizing, humiliation, retaliation, sabotage/thwarting, manipulation in many forms, secrets, intentional omission and withholding, bankrupt assumptions, favoritism, sexist dog-whistles, campaigning, gaslighting, blame-shifting, etc.  These can be subtle and take time to see clearly, but they are basically abusive, manipulative and toxic behaviors. To be clear, there is zero emotional and psychological safety. 

Even with recent changes, things persist. It's how people have been conditioned to operate, but it's far from safe, healthy or professional. Many lack the ability to critically self-reflect and own their contributionship, preferring to deny and blame-shift  in order to protect their ego and image. 

You can succeed in this environment if you are cunning, with a flare for the machiavellian (self-interest trumps all;  you're comfortable with manipulating others and the truth; the ends justify the means; you're shameless about it.) Or you're a robot and able to dissociate from it. Or, maybe you're willing to compromise your moral integrity for one reason or another. 

If you do join, keep your wits about you and your back to the wall.

pros: Beautiful location, friendly people, food services are high quality.
cons:
Benefits are -very expensive- especially if you have kids, not family-friendly leave policies for staff. Maternity leave is a mess. Managers can be great or terrible and HR can't help. Whole place is an angry mess with COIVD. 

WORST OF ALL: University will grant an annual cost of living raise to the whole department but then the management gets to "adjust" that raise based on performance ratings that can never be above a certain level. Your raises are NEVER what your letter rom HR says it is, always 0.5-1% less. They tell you it's because high-achievers get the difference but in 10 years of asking I've never found someone who will admit to getting that higher raise. I think they are pocketing the difference.

review_title: I look forward to coming to work everyday.
pros: Benefits/Salary are decent.  I work as part of a great team of people in one of the academic science departments, all of my co-workers are great as well.  The campus is beautiful.  We get approximately 21 paid holiday days each year, on top of 2 weeks personal vacation time, and 1 sick day per month (which accumulates year to year).  Plus the academic calendar allows for time off between semesters/over the summer easily.
cons:
One of the biggest shared gripes between employee's is the parking situation on campus.  Everyone is assigned parking based on a specific lot to park in, as opposed to Faculty/staff - student parking (which is the way I think it should be).  Over breaks and off-semester, sometimes it might be necessary to park closer to your office building than your assigned parking lot - Faculty and staff should not be ticketed while the students are away - but we are if we get caught parked in a lot we are not assigned to.

Needs to be more consistent COLI's and merit increases on par with other major universities.

review_title: Good place to be a TA
pros: Generally low stress environment.  Great opportunity to have graduate education paid for, and receive a small finanacial benefit yourself.  Great for learning how to teach, and learning how to interact with students on a one-on-one basis.
cons: TA experiences can vary.  Some TAs have signfiicantly more grading than others, and have much more responsiblity.  Other TAs tend to only have a very small amount of work for the same compensation.  Also, the pay is very poor.

pros: Nice campus, some very dedicated employees.
cons: No surprise for a conservative, Catholic institution.  Aside from the above, women face a particular challenge. The University makes a great show of "participatory" management, but it is top down, with major decisions made without true collaboration and input. The lack of unethical and amoral behavior, and complete lack of appropriate response is tough on morale. Too many people are too comfortable looking the other way.  Last place in the world I would advice a woman faculty member to work.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: This job gave me great management skills. Although some nights were especially busy, and I never took a break, the majority of nights were relaxed. And,  in-between tasks I could catch up on homework.
cons: Extremely low pay. Lack-luster effort by student employed staff. Late nights and early mornings. Overall, maybe more work than you are getting paid for, and the job has no concrete role. I did everything from oversee 10,000 sq feet to change toilet paper.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Villanova, PA
pros:
The campus.

Most of the professors willing to help.
cons:
Even if, I put the campus in pros as a graduate student I'm not allowed to live on campus. Beside this the commuting in the region is very difficult. It is quite difficult to live around without a car. Since school is located in a high income region outside parking isn't allowed so you have to purchase parking permit. With current construction, the parking lot for commuting students is moved to furthest possible location (starting from 2017). 

There isn't any health insurance for students. If you cannot find a cheap one you will be forced to buy school health insurance and it cost a little more than your one month stippen.

So, if you have any other option, put villanova at the end of your list.

pros: Good benefits, decent time off. It's a school job so summers can be light and there are lots of holidays. Kind of like a state job, but with more time off.
cons: I would not recommend Villanova in its current condition to IT professionals. Recent lay-offs and outsourcing of IT work show that Villanova is working on trimming its IT departments and I wouldn't count on long-term job security for the foreseabile future.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Villanova, PA
pros: Nice location and campus. A small group of students so you can show yourself better. A good place to get scholarship for masters. a great mechanical engineering team, professors and students and facilities
cons: Fewer opportunities,facilities and funding for research projects. Smaller faculty group in graduate engineering than other big universities. Electrical engineering is less famous than Mechanical engineering.

review_title: Great to be a student...everyone else on the other hand...
pros: Staff and faculty alike really care about the students. Many are willing to go above and beyond. Prestigious reputation.
cons: Everyone knows everyone and everything about them. This makes going to HR difficult when you have a problem because you fear word will get back around. Employee benefits are sub-par and the online course structure is a mess.

review_title: Creative implementation of the latest Instructional Technologies using appropriate professional visual multi-media, wor.
job_title: Instructional Technologies Instructor in Villanova, PA
pros: Considerate, dedicated Villanova Family produced award-winning results in the most wired campus. I enjoyed working here, and often stayed in the lab much longer in order to study and learn new software in order to implement the very best work. The results were rewarding, and I was later able to create my own web page in my spare time on weekends.
cons: This position only offered while a student.

review_title: Overall a good experience, but humanities are not a priority
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Villanova, PA
pros: Professors in my department were great. I have very few complaints. I had a ton of access to them, felt like I was really helping their overall mission to educate. I was treated like an adult, which goes a long way in academia.
cons: The Catholic culture was a little oppressive, but never in the classroom. But it was a bummer to have students citing Bible verses as actual evidence in serious essays.

pros: Salary is higher than some other universities in the area, benefits are good but health insurance plans getting more costly every year, campus is beautiful, plenty of time off.
cons: There is a very stagnant way of running things.  "This is the way it's always been done" and they don't like suggestions of change.  Veteran staff members are very cliquey to the point of being bullies and no one will do anything about it.  There is very definite favoritism.  A very secretive, untrusting environment.

pros: Very good place to work. I really like the work place, and the management is very supportive. The professors here are very helpful and great work culture.
cons: Salaries for graduate students when compared to other universities are quite low. However, they should be sufficient for a student.

pros: Villanova prefers a lot of freedom to pursue the research you're passionate about.  The staff has experience in many different areas and all of the professors are willing to contribute any help they can.
cons: Due to the small size of the program, there are sometimes issues obtaining the resources necessary to complete some research.  This is common and smaller research unversities.

pros: We have some of the best opportunities, that a job can offer
cons: they don't take pride in there wokers, which are amazing.

pros: Great people to work with. Great sense of community. Management is open to innovation and new ideas. The students are focused and easy going.
cons: Not much that I can really think of. As with most higher ed positions, there's not a lot of room for upward mobility as many people do not leave.

cons: Some of the graduate courses aren't taught very well or just don't hold much purpose. Overall they were good but a couple weren't satisfying.

review_title: It is a great place to work.
pros: Education is a very fulfilling and rewarding career. It is an amazing school that allows you to reach those looking to learn.
cons: As an adjunct professor, teaching opportunities can be limited. I only wish there were more opportunities to teach more classes.
